title-group.article-title: Does Organizational Justice Matter in the Federal Workplace?

article-meta.aff: 2Andrew Young School of Policy Studies, Georgia State University, Atlanta, GA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Yoon Jik Cho, Assistant Professor, Department of Public Administration, Yonsei University, 50 Yonsei-ro, Seodaemun-gu, Seoul 120-749, South Korea. Email: yoonjikcho@yonsei.ac.kr

abstract.p: The theory of organizational justice has been supported by numerous empirical studies in the private sector. Although public administration scholars have investigated the fairness issue in pay and promotions, the main focus was confined to specific groups such as females and racial minorities. This research seeks to fill the gap by providing some generalizable findings. We investigate the justice issue by considering both individual- and organizational-level factors. By employing hierarchical linear modeling (HLM), the research examines whether the three dimensions of organizational justice—distributive, procedural, and informational justice—and several organizational-level factors affect four outcomes, including expectancy for career development, employee satisfaction, loyalty to senior leadership, and cooperation. The analysis confirms that the three dimensions of organizational justice are substantially associated with those employee attitudes, although organizational-level factors have little impact on them.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Fairness has been a main concern of every organization. During the past several decades, literatures in the organizational justice field have demonstrated the validity of the equity theory provided by Adams (1965). Fairness in both outcome distribution and procedure determining outcome substantially affects employee attitudes and behaviors. Empirical studies demonstrate that organizational justice leads to positive attitudes such as satisfaction with outcomes (e.g., pay, performance evaluation, promotion), organizational commitment, trust in management and supervisor, and positive evaluation of authority (Cohen-Charash & Spector, 2001; Colquitt, Conlon, Wesson, Porter, and Ng, 2001; Rubin, 2009; Schaubroeck, May, & Brown, 1994). It also facilitates positive behaviors such as organizational citizenship behavior (OCB), cooperation, and high level of performance while suppressing counter-productive behaviors, employee theft, retaliation, and withdrawal (Cohen-Charash & Spector, 2001; Colquitt et al., 2001; Hom, Griffeth, & Sellaro, 1984; Masterson, Lewis, Goldman, & Taylor, 2000; Skarlicki & Folger, 1997).

Nevertheless, one cannot find as much relevant research in the public management field as in the business management field. That does not mean that public sector scholars have not paid attention to the issue. They have investigated the fairness issue in pay and promotions in public bureaucracy. However, the focus was confined to specific groups such as females and racial minorities (e.g., La Noue and Sullivan, 1995; Lewis, 1998; Lewis and Oh, 2009; Mani, 1999). In other words, few studies with a generalized approach to the issue of organizational justice have been conducted (See Rubin (2009) and Choi (2011) for exceptions). Seeking to fill this gap, this research provides empirical evidence for the importance of organizational justice within federal agencies.

This research is guided by two research questions. First, “Does organizational justice matter within federal agencies?” By considering both individual- and organizational-level factors, the current research tests whether the three dimensions of organizational justice—distributive, procedural, and informational justice—are associated with several outcomes, including expectancy for career development, employee satisfaction, loyalty to senior leadership, and cooperation. It also examines several organizational factors, including the level of discrimination in each federal agency. Second, the research asks, “What are the relative effects of the three dimensions of organizational justice?” Previous studies insisted on the two-factor theory, the main argument of which is that distributive justice has larger leverage for specific, personal outcomes than procedural justice, whereas procedural justice is more influential on general, organizational outcomes than distributive justice (Lind and Tyler, 1988; Sweeney and McFarlin, 1993; Thibaut and Walker, 1975). Out of the four dependent variables, the first two outcomes— expectancy for career development and employee satisfaction—reflect personal outcomes, whereas the latter two—loyalty to senior leaders and cooperation —present a general evaluation of the organization.1 Accordingly, this research tests whether the two-factor theory is also applicable to public bureaucracy.

To test these ideas, we integrate several data sources. The 2008 Federal Human Capital Survey is employed to measure individual-level factors, whereas several data sources, including FY 2009 Complaints data by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC), U.S. government manual, and federal budget data published on the official website of the U.S. Government Printing Office (www.gpoaccess.gov), are used to measure organizational-level factors. Hierarchical linear model (HLM) analysis examines the assumed relationships. The following section summarizes the major findings of organizational justice research as well as illustrates the three major dimensions of it. Then, a research framework is provided with an explanation of each component of the framework. After describing the research method and analysis results, we discuss major findings, limitations, and implications of the current research.

sec.title: Brief Review of Organizational Justice
sec.p: Although the study of equity can be traced back to the early 1960s, one can observe the prosperity of organizational justice research during the1990s. (Cohen-Charash & Spector, 2001; Colquitt et al., 2001). In its early days, the focus was on distributive justice, which primarily concerns the fairness of outcome distribution (e.g., equitable allocation of goods, wealth, and power among individuals) (Adams, 1963, 1965). Scholars found that perceived injustice in outcome distribution leads to dissatisfaction, decreased efforts, and turnover (Adams, 1965; Homans, 1961). After realizing that distributive justice cannot solely explain the perception of injustice, scholars began to focus on the procedure through which outcomes are decided (Greenberg, 1987). The study of procedural justice thus emerged as another dimension of organizational justice.

Although the two dimensions, distributive and procedural justice, have constituted the main dimensions of justice for decades, scholars have recently observed another dimension called interactional justice, which focuses on the quality of interpersonal treatment and information received. Reflecting the definition, interactional justice is comprised of two subdimensions, including interpersonal justice and informational justice (Bies & Moag, 1986; Cropanzano & Randall, 1993; Lind & Tyler, 1988). Several meta-analyses have revealed that the three dimensions—distributive, procedural, and interactional justice—are closely related and interact with each other, whereas they still constitute separate dimensions of organizational justice (Cohen-Charash & Spector, 2001; Colquitt et al., 2001; Greenberg, 1986). Each dimension and its expected effects are discussed below.

sec.title: Distributive justice
sec.p: According to Homans (1961), distributive justice is realized when all people gain the same profit-investment ratio. Applying the concept to the workplace, Adams (1963) argued that hard-working employees expect to receive reasonable outcomes such as payment, appraisal, or promotion. If they perceive inequality in the profit-investment ratio, the perception of injustice leads to various negative outcomes (Adams, 1965); attitudinal outcomes include dissatisfaction, anger, resentment, and a motivation to restore equity (Austin & Walster, 1974; Averill, 1979; Steil, Tuchman, & Deutsch, 1978), whereas behavioral outcomes are lowered motivation, employee theft, and turnover (Adams, 1965; Crosby, 1984; Greenberg, 1982, 1990b). In other words, when employees perceive distributive injustice, they may select to stop learning, be indolent, and even leave the organization, which cause organizations to incur substantial costs (Cropanzano & Randall, 1993; Lawler & Jenkins, 1992; Mark & Folger, 1984; Martin, 1986). On the other hand, perceived distributive justice leads to increased employee satisfaction and performance, reduced absenteeism and turnover, and participative organizational cultures (Greenberg, 1990a; Lawler & Jenkins, 1992).

sec.title: Procedural justice
sec.p: Besides the distribution of outcomes, the procedure determining outcomes matters. Defined as a legal decision-making process through which fair outcomes are determined (Thibaut and Walker, 1975), procedural justice enhances employee commitment to their organizations, trust in management, harmony in organization, and job satisfaction (Martin & Bennett, 1996; Mossholder, Bennett, Kemery, & Wesolowski, 1998). On the other hand, if people perceive the processes unfair, that leads to higher turnover intention, higher levels of conflict (Cropanzano & Baron, 1991), poor work attitudes (Daly & Geyer, 1995), less organizational citizenship behaviors (Malatesta & Bryne, 1997), and lower job performance (Cropanzano & Prehar, 1997).

Although procedural justice is commonly assumed as a separate dimension, some researchers have found that procedural justice and distributive justice are interrelated rather than completely independent. For example, scholars found that, when employees feel confident on fairness in procedure, they are more willing to accept the outcome distribution as impartial (Cropanzano & Randall, 1993; Greenberg, 1990a). In spite of the perceptual overlap between distributive and procedural justice (Thibaut & Walker, 1975), scholars also find some distinctions. The two-factor theory argues that distributive justice and procedural justice are predictive of different types of results (Folger & Konovsky, 1989). Procedural justice was found to be more closely related to general evaluations of the whole organization (e.g., organizational commitment, evaluation of supervisor), whereas distributive justice is more influential in determining personal and specific outcomes (e.g., pay satisfaction, job satisfaction, satisfaction with performance appraisal) (Alexander & Ruderman, 1987; Folger & Konovsky, 1989; Lind & Tyler, 1988).

sec.title: Interactional justice
sec.p: Interactional justice focuses on how decision-makers behave during the enactment of the decision-making procedure (Bies & Moag, 1986), which requires consistent and unbiased decision-making and delivery of information, timely feedback, and polite treatment of employees (Folger & Bies, 1989; Tyler & Bies, 1990). The concept has two subdimensions—interpersonal justice and informational justice. The former concerns interpersonal treatment of employees, whereas the latter deals with the quality of information employees obtain from communications with their supervisor or managers (Greenberg, 1993). Regarding interpersonal justice, fair treatment from supervisors and coworkers is negatively related to job distress and aggressive behaviors (e.g., yelling, criticizing, and cursing as well as physical assault; Ladebo, Awotunde, & AbdulSalaam-Saghir, 2008). On the other hand, the failure of doing that leads to negative emotion, reduced work effort, moral outrage, and turnover (Stecher & Rosse, 2005). For informational justice, even when employees receive negative outcomes, they willingly accept those outcomes as fair if clear and complete explanations are provided (Bies & Shapiro, 1987). Kim (2009) found that informational justice is substantially associated with reduced turnover intention.

Although some scholars consider interactional justice as a part of procedural justice (Cropanzano & Greenberg, 1997), others distinguish them by arguing that interactional justice is more individual-oriented than procedural justice. Whereas distributive justice and procedural justice are embedded in specific resource exchange contexts, interactional justice is evaluated in daily communication between supervisors and employees without detailed resource allocation decisions (Bies, 2005). Because of this characteristic, interactional justice has a stronger impact on employees’ reactions to supervisors or senior leaders and to the immediate work environment than distributive and procedural justice (Malatesta & Byrne, 1997; Masterson et al., 2000). Accordingly, interactional justice is closely related to behaviors and attitudes of immediate supervisors and leaders (Malatesta & Byrne, 1997), whereas procedural justice emphasizes overall structure and procedure of decision-making (Thibaut & Walker, 1975).

sec.title: Justice Research in the Public Sector
sec.p: The previous review introduced substantial research on organizational justice, mostly from the business management field. Then, what does the justice research in the public sector tell us? Although one cannot find many studies directly dealing with the issue, the existing research stresses the importance of justice in public organizations. Kurland and Egan (1999) compared the perception of fairness between private and public workers, and found that public workers perceive a lower level of distributional and procedural justice than do workers in the private sector. They found the reason from bureaucratic pathologies, but more research is required to confirm that. Regardless of the reason, the result implies organizational justice might be more required in the public bureaucracy. Recent research also stresses the role of organizational justice. Rubin (2009), for example, revealed that procedural justice is positively associated with satisfaction, trust in managers, and lower turnover intention in the Department of Defense. Choi (2011) found that higher levels of distributive, procedural, and interpersonal justice are positively related to job satisfaction and trust in management, whereas they are negatively associated with turnover intention of employees. These existing findings shed light on the value of justice research in the public management field.

sec.title: Research Framework
sec.p: Figure 1 provides the framework of this research. Three dimensions of organizational justice—distributive, procedural, and informational justice—are included as major independent variables.2 They are expected to positively affect four outcomes: The first two, expectancy for career development and employee satisfaction, present personal outcomes, whereas the latter two, loyalty to senior leadership and cooperation, are organizational outcomes.

All four outcomes are important indicators of employee attitudes and behaviors, and their importance cannot be underestimated within federal agencies. To public employees, the opportunity for development can be more critical in that they may have chosen the profession out of the public service motivation. Although the pay level is usually lower than that of private workers, public employees will be satisfied when they can achieve public interest by showing their potential in an advanced position. Moynihan and Pandey (2007) revealed that career development works as an effective extrinsic motivator to employees. According to one recent survey, career development opportunity is the strongest motivating factor of young generations whose birth date ranges from the mid-1970s to the early 2000s (Lunsford, 2010). Several studies have also demonstrated that opportunity for career development is substantially related to job satisfaction (e.g., Wright & Kim, 2004; Ellickson, 2002).

By measuring “the need deficiencies that instigate goal directed behaviors,” (Jurkiewicz, Massey, & Brown, 1998, p. 233) scholars investigated satisfaction extensively. Highly correlated with commitment and performance, satisfaction is a critical factor evaluating the overall well-being of employees. Low level of satisfaction is likely to lead turnover of employees, which is a serious loss to federal agencies. Furthermore, when considering the upcoming challenge of the baby boom generation’s massive retirement, fulfilling employee satisfaction and lowering their turnover are critical tasks for the federal government.

Considering the importance of leadership, loyalty to senior leadership is another critical factor influencing employees’ attitudes and behaviors, which leads to high performing organizations. It is shown to be closely related to employee performance (Earley, 1986) and citizenship behavior (McAllister, 1995). On the other hand, a low level of loyalty will lead to a high level of monitoring and frequent turnover (Currivan, 1999).

Finally, cooperation is a prerequisite for successful innovation and performance improvement, both within and between organizations (Deery & Iverson, 2005; Norris, 1990; Steiner, 2003). Two specific indicators of cooperation—teamwork and knowledge sharing—were employed in the current research. Given the current trend of collaboration and network governance, knowledge sharing is further valued and team arrangements are more frequently used in the federal workplace (Agranoff, 2007; Ingraham & Jones, 1999; Norris, 1990).

The expected relationships between the three dimensions and expected outcomes are obvious from the equity theory. According to the perception of fairness of different aspects, employee response will be different. As Adams (1965) illustrates, employees’ attitudes and behaviors are changed by the comparison of the ratio of their work outcomes to work inputs with that of others. If they perceive justice, they will respond with positive attitudes and behaviors. Otherwise, they will withdraw such positive attitudes and negatively respond to perceived unfairness. Social exchange theory also helps explain those relationships. Defined as “voluntary actions of individuals that are motivated by the returns they are expected to bring from others,” (Blau, 1964, p.91) social exchange includes both material and psychological benefits (Whitener, Brodt, Korsgaard, & Werner, 1998). Because employees are commonly involved in exchange relationships with supervisor and top management (Eisenberger, Huntington, Hutchison, & Sowa, 1986; Graen & Scandura, 1987), justice can be considered as an input from supervisors and top management. When employees perceive a high level of justice from their management, reactions to higher authority will be positive. On the contrary, under discrimination, the reaction of employees will be negative (e.g., decreased motivation, retaliatory behaviors, high turnover intention) (Masterson et al., 2000; Setton, Bennett, & Liden, 1996). This line of reasoning can be applied to the four expected outcomes. As many studies already confirmed (e.g. Lawler & Jenkins, 1992; Martin & Bennett, 1996; Martinez-Tur, Peiro, Ramos, & Moliner, 2008; Mossholder et al., 1998; Wooten and Cobb, 1999), employees are more likely to be satisfied and have higher expectancy for career development when they perceive a high level of organizational justice. Furthermore, as the social exchange theory predicts, higher levels of loyalty and cooperation will follow by responding to the enhanced organizational justice. Four hypotheses are examined.

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1a: Three dimensions of organizational justice—distributive, procedural, and informational justice—are positively associated with expectancy for career development.
Hypothesis 1b: Three dimensions of organizational justice—distributive, procedural, and informational justice—are positively associated with employee satisfaction.
Hypothesis 1c: Three dimensions of organizational justice—distributive, procedural, and informational justice—are positively associated with loyalty to senior leadership.
Hypothesis 1d: Three dimensions of organizational justice—distributive, procedural, and informational justice—are positively associated with cooperation.

sec.p: Regarding the relative influence of the three dimensions of organizational justice, we accept the basic argument of the two-factor theory: Distributive justice is more influential for individual and specified outcomes, whereas procedural justice is more prominent for organizational and general outcomes (Folger & Konovsky, 1989). Accordingly, distributive justice is expected to have a greater influence on expectancy for career development and employee satisfaction (individual outcomes), whereas procedural justice is expected to have greater leverage on loyalty to senior leaders and cooperation (organizational outcomes). Although no such established theory for interactional justice exists yet, one can conjecture that interactional justice, composed of interpersonal and informational justice, will be influential for outcomes related to leaders who interact with employees. The research therefore assumes that informational justice, which is examined in the current research, will have greater leverage on loyalty to senior leadership than distributive and procedural justice in that the outcome is closely related to leader behaviors and attitudes (Malatesta & Byrne, 1997). We test the ideas with the following hypotheses.

list-item.p: Hypothesis 2a: Distributive justice is more strongly associated with career development opportunity than procedural justice.
Hypothesis 2b: Distributive justice is more strongly associated with employee satisfaction than procedural justice.
Hypothesis 3a: Procedural justice is more strongly associated with loyalty to senior leadership than distributive justice.
Hypothesis 3b: Procedural justice is more strongly associated with cooperation than distributive justice.
Hypothesis 4: Informational justice is more strongly associated with loyalty to senior leadership than distributive and procedural justice.

sec.p: Other than the three dimensions of organizational justice, we control several individual-level factors. Intrinsic motivation, motivation coming from enjoyment of work itself, is included in the model because it has been demonstrated as a main driver of motivation, which makes a substantial difference in employee attitudes and behaviors (Deci & Ryan, 2004). Providing enough resource, one element of perceived organizational support, enhances positive attitudes and behaviors (Eisenberger et al., 1986). This research also considers a series of demographic factors, including supervisory status, agency experience, gender, and racial minority. Employee attitudes might be affected by his or her position. For example, employees in higher positions may have greater expectancy for progress and higher satisfaction by exercising more discretion and perceiving themselves as representatives of the organization (Gould-Williams & Davies, 2005). On the other hand, if they are disappointed with their authorities as they progress within the organization, they may show a lower level of satisfaction. Although we do not specify the direction of relationships, the supervisory status is controlled in that it may differentiate employee attitudes and behaviors. By reflecting the knowledge and skill development, agency experience may have an influence on outcome variables. Like the supervisory status, there are competing arguments. Although experienced workers might be valued by cumulated knowledge and skills earned through the experience (Tesluk & Jacobs, 1998), they can be less valued if perceived as people who are less flexible and slow to respond to changes (Lyon, Hallier, & Glover, 1998). Scholars have noted that females and minorities have been disadvantaged in career opportunity (Landau, 1995; Olson & Becker, 1983), which may lead to a lower level of satisfaction and loyalty. However, Roehling, Roehling, and Moen (2001) reported that females showed a higher level of loyalty to leadership than males.

Several organizational-level factors, including the level of discrimination, status of independent agency, and agency budget, are considered for the analysis. Like the reasoning of the three dimensions of organizational justice, the equity theory enables us to assume a negative relationship between the level of discrimination and employee attitudes. When federal employees work in agencies where discrimination is pervasive, they are more likely to have lower expectancy for career development as well as lower level of satisfaction, loyalty, and cooperation. Agency status indicates whether an agency is independent or embedded within a Cabinet Department. Independent agencies commonly work with more discretion and less constraints, which may affect employee attitudes and behaviors. Reflecting organizational size, agency budget is expected to have relationships with employee attitudes. By having more resources and well-established procedures, large agencies may contribute to the well-being of employees. On the other hand, they may have a more hierarchical and complicated structure, which leads to negative outcomes because of weak coordination. With these mixed expectations, the plausible effect of budget size is controlled.

sec.title: Data and Measurements
sec.p: The individual-level factors were measured by the 2008 Federal Human Capital Survey (FHCS). Conducted every two years since 2002, this survey, administered by the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM), has measured the perceptions of federal employees (U. S. Office of Personnel Management, 2009). Stratified random sampling was used for full-time, permanent employees working in agencies listed in the President’s Management Council, and 212,223 out of 417,128 selected employees responded to the self-administered web survey, representing a 51% response rate (U. S. Office of Personnel Management, 2009).

Table 1 illustrates the measures of individual-level variables. This research examined three dimensions of organizational justice, including distributive, procedural, and informational justice. Because proper measures of interpersonal justice were not available in the 2008 FHCS, only informational justice was investigated as one dimension of interactional justice. The confirmatory factor analysis differentiated the three dimensions of justice.3 Except demographic factors, all variables were measured by multiple measurements, most of which had an acceptable Cronbach’s alpha value. Mean values were used to combine multiple items.

sec.p: Several data sources were employed to measure organizational-level factors. We used the EEOC complaints data in FY 2007 as a proxy measure of the level of discrimination within federal agencies. The federal government has endeavored to make its workplace just and free of discrimination. Several statutes, including Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) of 1967, the Equal Pay Act (EPA) of 1963, the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Rehabilitation Act), and the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act (GINA) of 2008, prohibit the discrimination in employment based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin, disability, age, and any other genetic information (EEOC, 2009). EEOC has issued the complaint data since 2003 to evaluate the performance of federal agencies in promoting equal employment opportunity, and the data can be used as a proxy measure presenting the level of discrimination in each federal agency. Independent agency status is measured by referring to the U.S. government manual published by the National Archives and Records Administration. Agency budget of FY 2007 was measured by using the federal budget data published on the official website of the Government Printing Office (www.gpoaccess.gov). Evaluated in millions of dollars, budget data refers to the net budget authorities distributed to federal agencies.

sec.title: Analytic Method
sec.p: The current research used hierarchical linear modeling (HLM) to answer the research questions. Because it assumes that both individual- and organizational-level factors affect dependent variables measured at the individual level, HLM becomes a suitable analytic method. According to Steenbergen and Jones (2002), HLM identifies higher-level factors causing heterogeneity across groups while not losing model efficiency. Accordingly, besides individual-level factors, we examined whether organizational-level factors affect four outcome variables. Below is the HLM equation estimated by this research.

This research assumes that the effects of three dimensions of organizational justice are randomly varied across federal agencies (represented by u1j, u2j, and u3j) besides their fixed effects (γ10, γ20, and γ30). Organizational-level factors are expected to affect outcome variables (γ01, γ02, and γ03), and a random agency element is also assumed (u0j). However, we do not assume that organizational-level factors interact with three dimensions of organizational justice.

sec.title: Test of Common Method Bias
sec.p: One explicit limitation of the current analysis is that both individual-level variables and dependent variables came from the same data source, the 2008 FHCS. Podsakoff and Organ (1986) indicated that the overall positive attitudes of survey respondents may affect all of their responses. Thus, it is plausible that the regression coefficients are inflated when independent and dependent variables rely on the same survey data, the problem of which is called common method bias. One straightforward way to diagnose the seriousness of the bias is using Harman’s single-factor test, which conducts the principal component factor analysis for all variables in the model. If only one factor is retained and it explains most covariance, the bias is serious (Podsakoff, MacKenzie, Lee, & Podsakoff, 2003). The analysis of the current data shows that six factors were retained, and the largest factor explained 29% of the covariance. The result implies that the bias is not so serious as to make our analysis invalid even though it may still inflate regression coefficients.

sec.title: Descriptive Statistics
sec.p: Table 2 explains the zero-order correlations among variables included in the model.4 The three dimensions of organizational justice were substantially associated with all four outcome variables. In addition, the three dimensions of organizational justice were found to be strongly correlated with each other, ranging from 0.65 to 0.70. From the organizational-level factors, the percentage of complainants within agencies was negatively associated with the four dependent variables. On the other hand, independent agency status and agency budget size were positively related to them. However, the coefficients of these organizational factors were not very large. The given dependent variables evaluated by individual perception seem to be largely affected by individual-level factors rather than organizational-level factors.

Regarding the summary statistics, cooperation had the highest mean value among the four outcomes (3.98), and loyalty to senior leadership had the lowest mean value (3.24). Whereas procedural justice and informational justice had similar mean values, distributive justice had the lowest mean value out of the three dimensions of organizational justice (3.02). In FY 2007, the average percentage of complainants was 0.005%. Selective Service System showed the highest percentage of complainants (0.032%), whereas 14 agencies had no complainants.

sec.title: Hierarchical Linear Model Analysis
sec.p: Table 3 shows the HLM analysis for career development and employee satisfaction. All three dimensions of organizational justice are substantially associated with both outcomes. As shown, fair allocation of outcomes, due process, and effective communication play crucial roles in determining employee perception of career development and satisfaction. For their relative leverages, the coefficients of distributive justice were larger than those of procedural justice for both outcomes. The Wald test demonstrated that the differences were statistically significant. The result partly supports the two-factor theory, which insists that distributive justice is more influential for personal outcomes. Interestingly, the leverage of informational justice was similar to or larger than that of distributive justice; clear communication was as critical as fair allocation of outcomes in determining employees’ expectancy for career development and their overall satisfaction.

sec.p: Intrinsic motivation had the largest coefficient for both dependent variables; employees who enjoyed their work were more positive about their opportunity of career development and had a high level of satisfaction. As shown, having enough resources also enhanced those outcomes. Employees with supervisory positions (except executives) were more positive than nonsupervisors for their development in the organization. On the other hand, executives were less satisfied than nonsupervisors. Racial minorities were more negative for their development and overall satisfaction than White employees. Regarding organizational factors, the percentage of complainants was positively associated with employee satisfaction, which means that employees working in agencies with a higher level of discrimination (a higher percentage of complainants) have a higher level of satisfaction than others. This is an unexpected result, which requires further research. In addition, one can confirm several random effects. The effects of distributive justice and informational justice are randomly varied across agencies for career development, whereas the effects of distributive justice and procedural justice are randomly varied across agencies for satisfaction.

The HLM analysis result of organizational outcomes is shown in Table 4. Like the previous analysis, all three dimensions of organizational justice were found to be significantly associated with both outcomes, loyalty to senior leadership and cooperation. The result confirms the two-factor theory; post-estimation showed that procedural justice had a significantly larger influence on both outcomes than distributive justice. However, it was informational justice that had the largest coefficient in the model. Clear communication seems to be a prerequisite to earn loyalty from subordinates and facilitate cooperation.

caption.p: HLM Analysis for Loyalty and Cooperation.

fn.p: Note: Restricted maximum likelihood estimation is used. *p < .05. **p < .01. ***p < .001.

sec.p: Having enough resources was positively associated with loyalty to senior leadership, the leverage of which was similar to that of intrinsic motivation. Regarding cooperation, employees who were intrinsically motivated perceived a higher level of cooperation. Among the demographic factors, except executives, employees with supervisory status had less loyalty than nonsupervisors. Similarly, employees with longer agency experience had a lower level of loyalty. The results require caution from top management in that seasoned employees and employees with managerial positions, who play critical roles with their institutional knowledge, had a lower level of loyalty to top management. Team leaders and supervisors perceived a higher level of cooperation than nonsupervisors although the coefficients were not large. Females and racial minorities showed a higher level of loyalty to senior leadership than males and White people, but females perceived a lower level of cooperation than males. None of the organizational factors were statistically significant. With the given data, the general evaluation of leadership and cooperation was not much affected by organizational-level factors. Rather, from organizational random effects, both loyalty to leadership and cooperation are randomly varied across agencies.

Consequently, the analysis demonstrated the importance of the three dimensions of organizational justice in influencing the given outcomes. Hypotheses 1a through 1d were confirmed accordingly. We also demonstrated hypotheses 2a, 2b, 3a, and 3d in that the results supported the two-factor theory; distributive justice had larger leverage on career development and satisfaction (personal outcomes) than procedural justice, whereas procedural justice had more influence on loyalty to senior leadership and cooperation (organizational outcomes) than distributive justice. The analysis also confirmed hypothesis 4 from the largest coefficient of informational justice in explaining loyalty to senior leaders. Informational justice was also shown to affect the other three outcomes substantially. As a third dimension of organizational justice, it deserves more attention from practitioners and scholars.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The current analysis provides a positive answer for both research questions. First, organizational justice matters. The individual-level analysis shows that the three dimensions of organizational justice, including distributive, procedural, and informational justice, are positively and significantly associated with employees’ expectancy for career development, satisfaction, loyalty to senior leadership, and cooperation. The result suggests that establishing fair practices deserves to be among the priorities of the federal government.

Second, regarding their relative effects, the current analysis supports the two-factor theory. Individual-oriented outcomes, including expectancy for career development and employee satisfaction, are influenced more by distributive justice than by procedural justice. On the other hand, procedural justice is more strongly associated with organizational outcomes, loyalty to leadership and cooperation, than distributive justice. Besides the confirmation of the existing theory, the research found the substantial role of informational justice within the federal workplace. It has the highest coefficients for three out of four outcomes examined.

The given results offer several practical implications. Because justice matters in federal agencies, top management should pay more attention to the organizational justice issue and find out what kind of policies and activities enhance the perception of three dimensions of organizational justice. Core activities will include establishing fair procedures in determining outcomes, allocating rewards based on those outcomes, and communicating the relevant information in an effective manner. These activities may serve as a cornerstone of all managerial initiatives. For example, they are the core requirements of performance management, one of the popular schemes in current management reform (Moynihan, 2008). Schermerhorn, Hunt, and Osborn (2008) discussed the following four core steps that performance management should take:
identifying and setting clear and measurable performance goals; measuring performance to monitor progress toward the achievement of goals; providing feedback on performance results; and utilizing performance appraisals to inform major personnel management decisions such as rewards and accountability. (p.155)

The first and second steps are related to procedural justice; to be successful, procedures of setting goals and performance standards as well as performance appraisal should be fair. When employees have an opportunity to participate in the first step and make their voices, they are more likely to have a higher level of procedural justice. Informational justice is related to the third step. Top management and managers should provide timely feedback to employees through the established communication channel. The content of communication will not be confined to feedback to individual performance. Rather, it will include the long-term and short-term goals and the priorities of the organization and subunits. Distributive justice is critical for the final step; performance appraisal, which serves as an objective standard, should be the basis of rewards such as promotion, extra pay, or recognition. When these steps are integrated as a whole by assuring the three dimensions of organizational justice, one can expect successful implementation of performance management.

The current analysis implies that organizational justice is also a valuable asset for successful career development. Distributive justice will influence the allocation of rewards and opportunities for development, whereas procedural justice is related to the fair and consistent decision-making procedure of selecting development program participants. Explanation of why and how a certain decision is made is an area of informational justice, which will minimize the backlash of employees who did not have development opportunity (Wooten & Cobb, 1999). Organizational justice will work as a lubricant for smooth operation of employee development programs.

When considering that the two-factor theory is well supported by the analysis, top management may use it as guidance. If the overall evaluation of organization suffers among employees, managers may want to prioritize procedural justice and focus on establishing fair procedures within agencies. On the other hand, to enhance individual motivation by fulfilling their desire for development, top managers may emphasize distributive justice. Besides, federal agencies should not underestimate the importance of informational justice. The current analysis result reveals the importance of communication. Delivering accurate information on time is critical, and the role is not confined to top management. Not only middle-level managers but also frontline supervisors are responsible for clarifying organizational goals and missions as well as giving feedback to employee performance.

The research has some limitations. The current analysis is not free from common method bias because individual-level factors and dependent variables come from the same data source. Although the bias is not serious, it still exists in the analysis result and may inflate the size of regression coefficients. The current analysis has cross-sectional design and does not test the causal relationships, which is another limitation. Longitudinal analysis is required to confirm the causal relationships assumed in the equity theory. In addition, because the current research uses archival data, we fail to examine the whole dimension of organizational justice: Interpersonal justice was not included in the model. Replicating the research with comprehensive measures of organizational justice will be required.

There are many topics to explore. First, using objective outcome measures is required to remove common method bias, which will firmly confirm the effect of organizational justice. Second, beyond the two-factor theory, one may want to develop a comprehensive theory incorporating the effect of interactional justice. This research reveals that informational justice, a subdimension of interactional justice, plays substantial roles for both individual and organizational outcomes. For a more comprehensive list of outcomes, one needs to explore which dimension of justice is more influential under what conditions. Because this research confines its scope to federal agencies, replication of the study at the state and local levels is required in that the importance of fairness cannot be underestimated in any agencies.

Finally, as a general property of the organization, organizational justice will lead to various positive outcomes within the workplace, including employees’ acceptance of any management strategy and system, higher satisfaction and commitment, and increased performance. Nurturing organizational justice as a valuable resource will pay off. More research on this important topic will provide practical guidance to public managers and help establish better managerial practices. It is our hope that this research will facilitate that systematic effort.

Although all dependent variables are measured at the individual-level, loyalty to senior leaders and cooperation are considered as organization-oriented outcomes in that they reflect general evaluation of top leadership and the level of cooperation within federal agencies.
Because the current research uses the archival data, interpersonal justice measures are not available. Thus, we test informational justice only as one subdimension of interactional justice.

Except the Chi-square test, most major goodness-of-fit indices showed acceptable values. Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA) is 0.062 (The acceptable value is the value lower than its threshold, 0.07). Standardized RMR is 0.025 (The value lower than 0.05 is acceptable.). normed fit index (NFI) and comparative fit index (CFI) are 0.99, and goodness-of-fit index (GFI) is 0.98. (The acceptable value of those indices is the value higher than its threshold, 0.90). The result demonstrates that the three dimensions of justice examined in the current research—distributive, procedural, and informational justice—constitute a higher-level factor, organizational justice.
Demographic variables were not shown in the table.

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Yoon Jik Cho is an assistant professor of Department of Public Administration at Yonsei University in Korea. His research focuses on role of trust in public management, human resources management, and leadership.

Na Sai is a doctoral student and a graduate research assistant in the Department of Public Management and Policy at Georgia State University. Her areas of specialization include education policy and nonprofit organizations.
